# Short description of the Study

Animals living with kin and nonkin should make social decisions based on the consequences for both direct and indirect fitness. Common vampire bats invest in stable cooperative relationships that benefit both components of inclusive fitness. To disentangle these two factors, the authors conducted two types of playback trials using a group of captive vampire bats with mixed kinship and varying rates of dyadic food sharing. Individuals were presented with two speakers in maze trials. Speakers played contact calls from different familiar conspecifics. In Experiment 1 (Past donor trials), 15 bats had to choose between between calls recorded from either a frequent or rare food donor, but both "callers" were related to a similar degree with the subject.
